STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 8, 2022
LENIER HOLSTON
Kalamazoo County DHHS
427 E Alcott Street
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
RE: License #: CP390201215
Kalamazoo County DHHS
427 E Alcott Street
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
Dear Mr. HOLSTON:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
8/1/2022-8/12/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a six-month provisional certificate
of approval will be issued. If you do not agree to a provisional certificate of approval or
fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP390201215
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: LENIER HOLSTON, Administrator
Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Kalamazoo County DHHS
Facility Address: 427 E Alcott Street
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
Facility Telephone #: (269) 337-5000
Original Issuance Date: 09/10/1993
Service Types: CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): 08/01/2022 -8/12/2022
Total No. Of Records No. of Records
Reviewed
No. of current licensed foster homes 57 9
No. of homes pending licensure 22 3
No. of Foster homes closed since the last inspection 15 3
No. of Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 32 9
No. of Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 21 8
No. of incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect
in foster care since last inspection 3 3
No. of incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 2 2
No. of children currently placed in licensed foster homes 36 1
No. of children discharged from licensed foster homes
since the last inspection 49 4
No. of children whose sibling groups were split n/a
No. of children who have had 3 or more placements n/a
No. of children with unlicensed relatives 36 1
No. of youth in independent living placement 4 4
No. youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection 9 3
No. of applicants evaluated for adoption since the last inspection n/a
No. of applicants denied a recommendation since the last
inspection n/a
No. of adoption placements since the last inspection n/a
No. of Child Adoption Assessments Completed n/a
No. of adopted children currently in supervision n/a
No. of children free for adoption more than 12 months n/a
No. of acceptable corrective action plans (not maltreatment
of foster children) submitted by this agency since the
last inspection 2 2
No. of current employees who have worked at the facility for:
More than a year 19 3
Less than a year 8 8
2

No. of Persons Interviewed:
Licensing Staff 1
Foster Care Staff 3
Independent Living Staff 1
Adoption Staff n/a
Supervisory Staff 3
Administrative Staff 2
Foster Parents n/a
Youth in Independent Living n/a
The following required records were on file and available for review:
Program Statement Yes No NA
Program Policies Yes No NA
Staff Training Records Yes No NA
Volunteer Supervision Policy Yes No NA
Income/Expenditure for current year, including IRS Form 990 Yes No NA
Foster Parent Training Records Yes No NA
Supervisory Ratio Yes No NA
Caseload Ratio Yes No NA
METHODS OF INSPECTION – B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
No. of licensed foster homes 60 3
No. of unlicensed relatives homes 15 3
No. of independent living youth n/a
No. of adoptive homes n/a
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 7
Birth Parents n/a
Independent Living Youth n/a
Relatives 3
Adoptive Parents n/a
Others (please identify person interviewed by role) n/a
3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of
competent staff to carry out the provisions covered by these
rules. The workload for each staff member shall not be more
than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker for
purposes of providing direct services in foster care, independent
living, adoption, or post adoption services or a combination
thereof.
11 of 11 direct foster care case carrying staff are not within caseload compliance,
with some staff carrying up to 22 cases. The chief administrator reports high
caseloads being the result of the agency currently being 48% staffed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
R 400.12213 Record Management.
An agency shall do all of the following with respect to
maintenance of required records:
(b) Keep each record in a uniform fashion.
11 of 16 open case files reviewed contained several documents that were uploaded
the week prior to the audit despite the documents having been due or completed
throughout the 9-month period under review. At least 3 of these files contained
nearly all documentation uploaded the week prior to the audit. The files are not being
maintained uniformly as ascribed per FOM 722-05.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417.
4

3 of 12 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
required information was provided to the caregiver timely, which would be confirmed
through the caregiver signature on the DHHHS-3307 and the timely upload of the
DHHS-3762 as well as a coordinating case contact documenting these were
provided.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
Renewal Inspection Report 8/18/2020, CAP Approved 9/10/2020
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of the
following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of the
change, except when prior notification would jeopardize the
child's care or safety. If prior notice is not provided, then the
agency shall notify the foster parent, at the time of the change,
why prior notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent's rights concerning the
change in placement.
1 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation of required
notifications when a youth's placement changed completed within the required
timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 8/18/2020, CAP Approved 9/10/2020
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
1 of 16 total open case files reviewed contained an Initial Service Plan completed
outside of the required timeframe by 5 days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
Renewal Inspection Report 8/18/2020, CAP Approved 9/10/2020
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
5

3 of 16 total open case files reviewed contained updated service plans completed
late by 6, 28, and 42 days, respectively.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
Renewal Inspection Report 8/18/2020, CAP Approved 9/10/2020
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010,
continues to reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and
is managing expenditures.
1 of 4 open IL files was missing one monthly IL packet which documents monthly
agreement and compliance with the IL contract.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS Policy requirements
except for the following:
ADM 1030 ADOPTION CASE RECORD RETENTION
After adoption finalization, all adoption records are closed. The
records must be kept in separate locked files and shall not be
open to inspection or copying, except as stated in disposition of
records in this item.
For both MDHHS and contracted adoption agency cases, the
local MDHHS office or contracted agency must retain all
adoption case records for one year after finalization of the
adoption. One year (between 12-13 months) past the adoption
finalization date, a contracted adoption agency must send the
original record to the local MDHHS office; copies must not be
maintained by the contracted adoption agency; see licensing
rule R400.12713-
Adoption Placement Record.
The local MDHHS office must forward all records (both MDHHS
adoptions and contracted agency adoptions) to MDHHS central
office within three months of receipt of file. The contracted
adoption agency or local MDHHS office must not retain any
adoption records of MDHHS-supervised children or dispose of
them in any way other than that described in this policy.
6

Records must be sent to:
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
Document Control Section
235 S. Grand Avenue
P.O. Box 30037
Lansing, Michigan 48909
Following the finalization of adoption, adoptive family files must
be retained in the local MDHHS office or contracted adoption
agency for three years and may be destroyed after the three-
year period. Any Criminal History Records Information (CHRI)
must be maintained and destroyed as outlined in SRM 200,
Fingerprinting.
There are several finalized adoption files in the office that are overdue for delivery to
Lansing by three months.
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and
the safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days of the FTM.
7

10 of 16 open case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all required
FTMs were held. The majority of the missing meetings were required for service plan
development and placement changes. Additionally, there were documented FTMS
for which no DHHS-1105s were uploaded. FTMs provide the needed documentation
that participants are involved in their service planning.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
Renewal Inspection Report 8/18/2020, CAP Approved 9/10/2020
FOM 722-06H CASE CONTACTS
CONTACT WITH CHILD'S CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in
the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If there is more than
one caregiver, such as a primary and secondary caregiver, the
caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the
secondary caregiver in the home at least once each quarter.
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement
Change
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with each child in the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement change.
CHILD IN A PARENTAL PLACEMENT
The contact standards detailed in this section are required
anytime a child is placed with their parent or legal guardian.
Residential or Institutional Setting
When a child is placed in a residential or institutional setting, the
caseworker must have contact with the case manager/therapist
assigned to the child, as described in this section.
MiSACWIS Documentation
Caseworkers must identify whether a private meeting, or safe
sleep verification for infants, occurred for each child participant
in the Participant screen within the Social Work Contact section
of MiSACWIS.
8

3 of 13 total open case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all required
face to face meeting with the youth were completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED as ISEP 6.21
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
Renewal Inspection Report 8/18/2020, CAP Approved 9/10/2020
FOM 722-06J RIGHTS OF CHILDREN IN FOSTER CARE
Within 30 calendar days of removal, the caseworker must review
and explain the DHS-5307, Rights and Responsibilities for
Children and Youth in Foster Care, and the agency's grievance
policy with the child, foster parents, caregivers, and parents. The
caseworker must be prepared to answer any questions the child,
parents, and caregivers may have.
After the document is reviewed the signatures of the child and
caseworker must be obtained. The parent or caregiver must sign
on behalf of the child, if the child is younger than 11 years old or is
unable to sign the document. The caseworker must complete the
information on the last page of the document with the applicable
contact information and provide all participants with a signed copy
and upload a copy to MiSACWIS.
Placement Change When a child under age 11 or who is
otherwise unable to sign the DHS-5307 changes placement, the
caseworker must review the DHS-5307 and the agency's
grievance policy with the new caregiver and obtain their
signature on the DHS-5307 within 30 days of the placement
change.
Documentation The DHS-5307 must be reviewed and re-
signed annually. The caseworker must document the review in
the social work contacts, and the caseworker must upload the
DHS-5307 to the Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS.
5 of 16 total open case files reviewed did not contain all signed DHHS-5307 forms
as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
FOM 722-08 ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
SUPERVISOR APPROVAL
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan within
14 calendar days of the report date.
9

1 of 16 total open case files reviewed contained an Initial Service Plan that was not
approved within the required timeframe. This approval was 17 days late.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
FOM 722-08A ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
Prior to finalizing, the caseworker and supervisor must review
the case service plan and all linked assessments and treatment
plans during a face-to-face meeting. Case service plan review
may occur during monthly case consultation (supervision).
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan within
14 calendar days of the report date.
4 of 16 total open case files reviewed contained Updated Service Plans that were
not approved within the required timeframe. These approvals were approved 1, 18
and 24 days late, respectively. The fourth USP was dated 6/26/22 and had not yet
been approved at the time of inspection making it currently 25 days late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED as FOM 722-09
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
Renewal Inspection Report 8/18/2020, CAP Approved 9/10/2020
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check yes
or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
10

the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
treatment plan, the caseworker must identify, and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the
treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
13 of 16 total open case files reviewed contained PATPs with either late or missing
signatures. The signatures determined to be late or missing included worker,
supervisor, parent, youth, and caregivers.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED as FOM 722-08C
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
Renewal Inspection Report 8/18/2020, CAP Approved 9/10/2020
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
11

8 of 25 total open and closed case files reviewed were either missing required action
summaries or contained action summaries that were either incomplete or not
completed timely. These action summaries would have documented placement
changes, worker changes, and case closure.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date to the following
 Foster care provider.
 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services (MDHHS) policy.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
12

11 of 16 total open case files reviewed did not contain all required updated and
signed medical passports.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED as FOM 801
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
Renewal Inspection Report 8/18/2020, CAP Approved 9/10/2020
PA 116 - Investigation, Inspection, and Examination of conditions,
722.120(1)(c) books, records, and reports
The department may investigate, inspect, and examine
conditions of a childcare organization and may investigate and
examine books and records of the licensee. The licensee shall
cooperate with the department’s investigation, inspection, and
examination by doing all of the following:
(c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the
department, and encouraging witnesses, such as staff and
household members, to provide accurate and truthful
information to the department.
7 of 25 total open and closed case files reviewed contained documentation that were
backdated, altered, or otherwise falsified. The documents involved were medical
passports, action summaries, initial placement outlines, medical consent to treat
cards and rights and responsibility forms. The documents that were falsified were all
uploaded the week prior to the audit, despite having signature dates throughout the
period under review. Some of the documents were competed by workers or
supervisors other than those currently assigned and were, at times, signed by
supervisors, using a worker's name and a backdated signature.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 When DocuSign is unavailable and electronic typed in names must be utilized as
signatures, the case record must reflect either in case contacts or through
document upload that the person whose signature is typed in has entered the
signature themselves and that the document was explained by the worker.
Ideally, an email from the signing person indicating that the document has been
explained to them and they agree to the document should be uploaded. In the
case a recipient agrees to the document via phone, a case contact should be
entered timely, a note made on the signature line of the documents indicating the
date it was provided and agreed upon and by what method it was
provided/discussed. A physical signature should be obtained as soon as able.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
13

 Consultation was provided regarding the auditing of case files either during
supervision or prior to approving case service plans to maintain compliance with
document completion and uploading timely.
 Consultation was provided regarding the completion of the Chief Administrator
Assessment.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were 3 incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
All three of the SER’s related to the child abuse/neglect during this licensing period
were reviewed. They were all found to have been completed accurately and
thoroughly with appropriate recommendations.
There were 2 incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
Both of the SER’s related to corporal punishment during this licensing period were
reviewed. They were all found to have been completed accurately and thoroughly
with appropriate recommendations.
AND
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective action plan was submitted in response to licensing interim
inspection report dated 11/19/2021 and was approved on 12/9/2021. Compliance
with that CAP has not been maintained as evidenced by 11 of the 17 violations
established during this period under review being repeat violations of those
addressed in the 12/9/2021 CAP. Additionally, 8 of the 11 repeat violations were
also established in the 2020 renewal inspection for which a CAP was approved
9/10/2020. Compared to the 2021 inspection, the number of incidents of each
violation has decreased slightly in areas such as; face to face visits with youth,
timely service plans, and FTMs, has increased in areas such as; action summaries,
5307s, and supervisory approval of service plans, and has remained the same in
areas such as; obtaining signatures on PATPs, and medical passports
The second corrective action plan was submitted in response to special investigation
report 2022C0212013 dated 7/8/2022 for which a CAP was approved on 8/4/2022.
The agency is in process of implementing the CAP, and compliance with the CAP
will be assessed for 6 months following the approval date.
The licensee received a copy of Act 116, the licensing rules promulgated under Act
116, and the terms of the license. The licensee failed to comply with Act 116, the
14

licensing rules promulgated under Act116, or the terms of the license and has
demonstrated willful and substantial violations when falsifying documentation and
failing to maintain complete youth files throughout the licensing period. The files
containing the falsified documents were from multiple supervisors and were
completed by multiple workers.
Chief Administrator Assessment- The chief administrator assessment was
submitted and reviewed on 8/12/2022. The chief administrator identified issues
related to staffing and pandemic related restrictions resulting in areas on non-
compliance.
Interviews – The staff interviewed all reported being supported by their peers and
immediate superiors. The foster care workers reported that high caseloads have
made it difficult to maintain compliance throughout the year. Two workers reported
that the current caseloads are overwhelming and unmanageable. The worker and
supervisors interviewed were asked about the falsification of documents. They all
reported that they were not given any directive to falsify files but were told to correct
anything they could prior to the inspection. One supervisor and one worker stated that
it was unclear to them what could be corrected in a file and made individual decisions
to create and backdate documents. Another supervisor was asked about a backdated
document with her signature. She stated that the document was from a case she
previously supervised and the worker she had been supervising at the time emailed
her the document to sign. The supervisor reported that the signature dates were
already filled in by the worker and she didn’t pay attention to them when adding her
signature.
VII. DCWL Analyst Concerns
No Safety Concerns Identified.
15

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the agency license be
modified to a First Provisional license.
August 12, 2022
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 8, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
16
